reasoning:
The critique targets the role of early lock-in/path dependence in motivating the need for early convergence and the “narrow target” framing. This is a relevant supporting consideration (the essay treats lock-in as an important blocker and repeatedly notes timing matters), but it is not the core of the essay’s main conclusions about the (un)likelihood of WAM-convergence, the prospects of partial convergence via trade, and the threat problem—those concerns can persist even with ongoing value drift. So centrality is moderate.

Strength is low-to-moderate because it mostly asserts, rather than argues, that post-AGI values will remain fluid and renegotiable and that intelligence overcomes path dependence. The position already contemplates extended reflection, bargaining over time, and also explicitly treats lock-in as contingent (a blocker to be analyzed further), not as a universal presupposition. Even if lock-in is less likely, that only partially relaxes early-convergence pressure and doesn’t by itself answer worries about divergence, motivational failure, threats, or institutions.

Correctness is mixed: it’s true that if there were no durable lock-in, some pessimistic implications from early trajectory-setting would weaken; but it overstates by saying the “entire aiming metaphor presumes” a single permanent lock-in and that the paper treats the future as “ballistic.” Clarity is high, dead weight is low, and it cleanly focuses on one issue.
title: Superintelligent value fluidity undermines the permanent lock-in assumption
